@reminisce 
What you said is right. But, I have seen some test cases failure with complete removal. Reason being a test case with no inputs(all params) results in no functions for llvm. I made changes for the failure test cases to let at least one input.

Conclusion here would be "we may not be able to have a graph compiled with precomute_prune pass  while no inputs (all params)". Though its not a realistic having a graph with no inputs.

cc @tqchen please advice on this change.

Currently x86 backend in under refactor #1993 .
I think it is better to merge that first. So you can stop all your changes on `topi/x86/*`.

@zhiics Tianqi has been pushing back on implementing a pass manager for the past couple weeks. He feels like we should wait until we have a few more passes and use cases before we go all in on designing the pass manager. I'm happy to build one sooner then later for various reasons which I'm happy to elaborate on.

I've checked a bit, but I don't find the right place for Vulkan, could you guys give me a link?
also another concern, notice that there are only gpu and cpu on CI, so if I checkin for other backend, since I have no env in my computer, how can I verify it?
BTW, these are links I found for other backends, also take a look and confirm, thanks!

openCL: yes. https://manpages.debian.org/testing/opencl-1.2-man-doc/fmod.3clc.en.html
metal: yes. https://developer.apple.com/metal/Metal-Shading-Language-Specification.pdf
rocm: yes. https://rocm-documentation.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ROCm_Compiler_SDK/ocml.html?highlight=fmod
nvptx: no. https://github.com/llvm-mirror/clang/blob/master/include/clang/Basic/BuiltinsNVPTX.def
@srkreddy1238 You are right, I encountered the same thing and added some special handling in compiler and runtime in my private branch. I should be able to upstream the work in a month.
Thanks @MarisaKirisame
Vulkan's intrinsics are defined here https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/codegen/spirv/intrin_rule_spirv.cc#L33

The main principle of passes as they should be conservative and be able to handle all the cases, so it is fine to not being able to prune graph with no variables. This problem can be resolved on NNVMv2(relay) by using a more formal constant folder.

Thank @tqchen for the explanation.

@srkreddy1238 While removing the early return solves the issue to a certain level, I'm worried that tweaking the `opt_level`to 1 in some unit tests may skip testing some important passes, such as operator fusion.

A quick fix for the problem of no functions for LLVM can be passing a graph attribute to the frontend indicating whether the `pre_graph` needs to be compiled and run, or just simply update the param names in the function `precompute_prune`.

The more correct way of fixing this should be adding special case handling in the compiler and runtime when no functions can be fed to LLVM.

Yeah, I though of other passed being ineffective with opt_level=1.
pre_graph option is too much effort to test scripts while finding exact test cases need this flag.

I think handling in LLVM to make a dummy module is an ideal option.
Yes, updated same in #1923

Thanks, @kevinthesun @nishi-t @zhreshold for reviewing and contributing. There has been some flux in changes of parameter naming, given that nms is not a standard operator.

 I would like everyone to have a discussion again about the parameter naming 
 as per https://docs.tvm.ai/contribute/code_review.html#deliberate-on-user-facing-api

Specifically, there is a bit inconsistency in current naming
- nms_topk have the prefix nms(operator name in the attr), while overlap_threshold don't.

Let us also refer to existing implementations and try to be consistent as possible
Since slice_like is not a conventional numpy op, let us put its support level as 10 for now, to mark it as experimental

Actually, it is a feature for some hardware accelerator which can't be binded. The pass is not essential for GPU or CPU. Using a pass will be flexible, user can add it in their own custom pass list, just like coproc_sync. And there will be no side-effect for current solution. @tqchen

@tmoreau89 As I'm implementing the driver for the modules, I'm not quite clear about whether the `fetch` module loads instruction streams from DDR via cache coherent ACP port, or it could load instructions through the lightweight AXI port. In addition, if it loads instructions via the ACP port, does it require any additional on-chip RAM store the instruction queue?

The CI's test_topi_depthwise_conv2d.py test error is because I have modified the schedule, which doesn't have `tile_c` and so on in previous schedule. But TopHub(fall back will use) doesn't contain my new schedule cfg. Maybe I need @merrymercy 's help to handle this situation.
@tqchen Changed per the request

For the first method, you don't need to change any test scripts. The root cause of failure comes from compiling a `pre_graph` with pure variable nodes. You just need to use the attribute to decide whether to skip compiling the `pre_graph` or not.

Anyway, the second method should be the most correct way of fixing this issue. I have it in my branch and can upstream it in a month if that's not too late.
@merrymercy Please check the test cases.

@tqchen:  Got it, sorry for the misunderstanding.  Updated with your recommentation.

Anything else you would like I am happy to do :-).

@tqchen thanks for the answer,
but anyway the tracing is require to write own runtime support, what do you think about generic solution written as shared library, with some options which could be applied by environment library. Looks like it would be an easy way to use it for the users.

For example "sanitizers" from llvm/compiler-rt have two parts:
1. Instrumentation pass.
2. Runtime support, which could disable/enable some features by environment variable.

The library can be build as unique dso and would require to manually link model with it.

The current features could likely be implemented using packed function calls, to define a set of tracing functions like you do but declare them as packed function.  Then optionally we could register these runtime function as a packed function, or registering different variant of it depending on whether tracing is on/off

So to summarize, I agree that tracing would need runtime support, but these runtime feature could likely be built around tvm packed function system

these are some intrinsics we've done the inplace for our target:
```
vadd(tvm_access_ptr(0.000000h, Res_UB_F16, 7936, 7936, 2), tvm_access_ptr(0.000000h, Res_UB_F16, 7936, 7936, 1), tvm_access_ptr(0.000000h, Res_UB_F16, 16, 128, 1))
copy_matrix_cc_to_ubuf(tvm_access_ptr(0.000000h, Res_UB_F16, 0, 63488, 2), tvm_access_ptr(0.000000h, Res_UB_F16, 0, 63488, 1))
```

more specific, we can add a backend hook here for Evaluate(intrinsics is always inside of Evaluate node)
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/pass/storage_rewrite.cc#L231

Thanks, @jroesch for the changes, I did a serious round of review. 

Besides the changes I suggested, I would recommend us to deliberate about the API choices of the function evaluate. In particular, while it is understandable that env could be a useful thing, it is a bit annoying to users who usually only evaluate an Expr. This is the same reason behind why we put expr in the first argument in most ir_passes and makes env optional. Here is a possible alternative proposal:

```python
engine = relay.Interpreter(env) # env is optional
x = relay.var("x")
# evaluate a free expression.
engine.evaluate(relay.add(x, x), binds={x: np.zeros((1,))})
# evaluate a function
engine.evaluate(f)(np.zeros((1,)))
```
@junrushao1994 can you help review this, @zhiics @slyubomirsky please take another round of look, we would like to bring this in as it is one of the major enabler of full compilation

Two more things added here,
1) ASIC may have instructions for tail, so both have and not have should be considered.
2) users may only use low level IR to develop operators, and integrate ops to other frameworks such TF, in this case, we can not do padding on graph level.
@yzhliu @ZihengJiang please also take a look

@xqdan Great points. I had similar thoughts.

I think introducing tailcondtion as a schedule option of split/tile might be a generic-enough solution, so user or autotuner can select among them based on their needs for a specific arch.
(b) and (c) should be two reasonable ones.
(a) can still be the default, so we don't break existing ones.
(b) should be a direct, simple extension on top of the current semantics (a), so some cases can gain performance benefit.
(c) should be also a good one, but might take more time to introduce, since it involves more transformation. We can gradually add it.

All of these are still orthogonal to tvm's future high-level IR. So co-design can still have its own value.

-L
@siju-samuel @junrushao1994  please review

@merrymercy I have looked into the error in http://ci.tvm.ai:8080/blue/organizations/jenkins/tvm/detail/PR-1970/21/pipeline/232#step-255-log-1230. There is one failing case of nchw conv2d on nvptx because tophub logs are invalidated in this pr. The fallback schedule from `fallback_with_reference_log` produced wrong conv2d result.
